record.text: NAWAPA is my Roman Empire
ah "The environmental damage that would be caused by that damned thing can't even be described. It would cause as much harm as all of the dam-building we have done in a hundred years."

Susquehanna
east branch, west branch or joined?
Same here! Since I guess Conewago Creek isn't a river...

It's eighty miles long and drains three counties (York, Adams, and Carroll).

I did not know this. All I knew was how it can smell pretty foul in downtown York in the summer.
This is near where I grew up but the Conodoguinet Creek would be closer to my home as a kid.
The Conewango Creek and the Allegheny River are my two hometown waterways ‚ù§Ô∏è
Same here! I've spent many a summer kayaking on both of them.
Conewago flows through my folks' back yard! My tributary is the Conestoga, but it's nice that all the many children of the Susquehanna can play together
Great river !
Dip your fanny in the Susquehanny!
My grandfather used to work at the Susquehanna hat company.
My father‚Äôs home river.

record.text: The Cuyahoga, which hasn't caught on fire in decades now!
Puyallup
Yoooo!!!! Went to high school there!! Was just reminded about the Fair the other day and got all nostalgic‚Ä¶
BTW you are not a ‚Äúcat owner.‚Äù  The cat owns YOU!
True üòÇ
Which school?  Just curious.  The Fair is great, they have wonderful concerts.
Puyallup HS. There were just two when I lived there: PHS and our rivals at Rogers. I was a Viking.
Right.  It‚Äôs bigger now!  Especially on South Hill.

üé∂You can do it at a trot. 
You can do it at a gallop. 
You can do it real slow 
So your heart won't palpitate. 
Just don't be late. 
Do the Puyallup.üé∂

ü§£üò∏
Are you a local?
From the PNW (but not Puyallup).  I remember hearing it and, well, how can you forget it? Felt like it needed to be shared!

Yes, it‚Äôs the theme song for the WA State Fair, you hear it on a lot of commercials in September.  The Fair, as you probably know, is held in Puyallup the town, through which the river flows, and continues through Tacoma and empties into the Puget Sound.

i think you mean the Puyallup Fair. 

this whole "washington state fair" thing is rinkydink.
Same thing, yes, I‚Äôm not fussy about the name

record.text: The Grand was mine until very recently - all the way down near its source in Jackson. It's a hell of a lot more impressive downriver.

I've been a detroit resident my whole life and I never knew this...

what the hell üò≠
There used to be before it was dammed! The Grand is mine too. üòä
There used to be a mile long set of rapids at the town site, but they were flooded with a series of low-head dams with the first dam built in 1866.

Little Cuyahoga/Cuyahoga but the Patuxent is on my list of Rivers to visit. Traced my mother's family to arriving in MD in the early 1700s and then they spent the better part of a generation on the Eastern shore of the Patuxent before heading West to Kentucky.

record.text: Apologies, but I am very protective of the Great Lakes.

Then I think we are on the same side. I loved living lakeside in Toronto and saw as much as I could of all five lakes during my time in Canada and the USA. One of the seven wonders of the natural world.
Kankakee River
My mother grew up in Kankakee. How very cool. üòä
River Crane
The mighty Nishnabotna.

Major: Columbia, Snake

Minor: Grande Ronde, Wallowa, Imnaha, Powder, Umatilla, Walla Walla

Minors 2: Lostine, Minam, John Day 

Creeks that are larger then some rivers on this thread:

Cathrine, Big Sheep, Prairie, Joseph
Can‚Äôt believe I had to scroll down this far to see the Columbia listed!

üé∂Green Douglas-firs where her waters cut through
Down her wild mountains and canyons she flew
From the Canadian Northwest to the Ocean so blue
Roll on, Columbia, roll on.üé∂

Ok, I‚Äôm feeling like less of a dope for singing this song when I posted

üé∂ Roll on, Columbia, roll on
Roll on, Columbia, roll on!
Your power is turning our darkness to dawn
So roll on Columbia roll onüé∂

(My dad was a big Woodie Guthrie fan, plus we had to sing this in school)
Haven't heard that one even though I live in the middle of the Columbia!
Yeahhhhh‚Ä¶. I suspect you‚Äôre younger than me. My parents and teachers were hippies, too. The Guthrie vibes were still going strong in the late 70s
Also I only moved here last summer, before my current house, I was much closer to the Willamette.
Maybe--it was the 70s when I sang it.  Music teacher had a big beard and played the guitar.

You are describing my dad (who is now in his 80s but still wears a big beard and plays the guitar)

He would also sing 
üé∂ Cigarettes and whiskey and wild wild women
They‚Äôll drive you crazy they‚Äôll drive you insane üé∂

‚Ä¶but only when my mom wasn‚Äôt in the car

We sang it in school, too!
There's a few bangers on Woody's Columbia River album
the Chattahoochee

The Fleet in London, now almost entirely underground running from Hampstead Heath and Highgate Ponds down through Clerkenwell and the City to Blackfriars into the Thames. One of London's great Lost Rivers.
Thief River
I got a package from Thief River Falls just last week.
Must have been from Digikey! My mom's family comes from Thief River Falls.
Could have been a parcel of lutefisk and lefse
Less likely to travel well, but true.
Would taste about the same either way I think.

The question I like is: which river have you crossed the most times in your life.

Mine is probably in order:

Charles

Merrimack
Mississippi
Saco
Pemigewasset
Androscoggin
Definitely the Severn, (in the UK). I live about 300 metres from it and cross it multiple times a week just from my running routes alone.

record.text: I didn‚Äôt know there was another Severn! I live by the Severn in Worcester in the UK.

images.alt: map of central Massachusetts with the towns I mentioned highlighted

record.text: I've been reading the Brother Cadfael mysteries, and I was so amused to learn that that area of the UK was simply copy-pasted onto the area where I grew up in Massachusetts. Worcester, Leominster, Shrewsbury, Shirley...

images.alt: map of central Massachusetts with the towns I mentioned highlighted

record.text: I bet most of them are pronounced differently in Massachusetts. In England, it's "Wooster", "Lemster" and either "Shroosbree" or "Shroesbree" (even the people who live there can't agree on that last one).
Wooster (Woostah), Lemon-stah, and Shroosbree here.

record.text: I think that Brits had one first.....

We were an unimaginative bunch when we arrived in new places. 

‚ÄúWe sailed from Plymouth‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs call this place Plymouth.‚Äú
NEWFOUNDLAND
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs name all the things after things in the place we left.‚Äù
Sabine
St. Mary's river, though I could technically pick the Potomac or Patuxent as well.
A foreign service life in rivers: Potomac, Nile, Thames, White Nile, Bou Regreg (plus a couple of very dry places‚Ä¶)
The Father of Waters, Old Man River, the Great River, the Mighty Mississipp
The mighty Umpqua
San Lorenzo
The Manawatu, New Zealand.

Rhode Island! 
(My dad was from Providence.)

My "home river" would have to be the Black Warrior River.
Yadkin!

record.text:
Growing up: Chicago River.
Now: Milwaukee River.

Pretty great rivers.

(Of course, my wife has me beat: the Mississippi, near its headwaters)
And I need to add the Liffey! I spent 10 years living right at the mouth of it, on the port.

I‚Äôm gonna tell you a big fat story, baby, about the Charles River 

(Also, a little bit the Saugatucket, and, much further south, the Monocacy)
As a kid the Namasket as an adult the Neponset.
where the Potomac and the Shenandoah meet.
Sabine River
@pearlriverflow.com
wooo
Unsure if I can claim the Pearl as my home river when I grew up on the shores of the Real Big Racist Reservoir‚Ä¶.

had my junior prom at rhodes on the pawtuxet lol
I can‚Äôt remember which dance I went to there for school but I know my nana and her sister used to go there when it was the place to be in it‚Äôs heyday

images.alt: Autumn on the River Wye looking downstream with majestic trees lining both banks
Aberdeenshire Dee in May with blue skies, white clouds. Rocky banks in the foreground. Gorse in flower and trees in full leaf.
River Coln. Aerial photo graph looking at the river flowing through green water meadows
Misty view of the River Evenlode in winter

record.text: I claim four home rivers. The Wye where I learned to fish for salmon. The Aberdeenshire Dee where I am happiest. The Coln where I work to teach fishing and improve the habitat. The Evenlode in the village where I live and along whose banks I walk my dog most days.

record.text:
Mine‚Äôs the mighty Merrimack of Masschusetts mill town fame

www.nps.gov/lowe/learn/h...

external.title: The Merrimack River - Lowell National Historical Park (U.S. National Park Service)
external.description: A brief history of the Merrimack River

record.text:
Lowell girl til I was 11!

I have a scar on my chin from falling while on a field trip to the mills when I was 5 lol

Me toooo!!

My youth was spent in Billerica and Chelmsford, and my father's business was in Lowell.
I‚Äôve passed that many a time
the OG Miskatonic
Amazing. Where on the Merrimack? I grew up in Groveland.
My people are from the greater Lowell area, settled there and worked in the mills after immigrating in the 1860s.
Wild! Irish immigrants from the same period for me working these mills. Our ancestors could've worked together üòÅ
I know for certain one side worked in the Talbot Mill in Billerica. Other side, we don‚Äôt have as much info, but I do have a great grandad who installed the slate roofs on many a Lowell landmark.

images.alt: Obituary from a newspaper. The text reads "Mr (redacted by poster) had been employed as an overseer of the Spinning Department at Talbot Mills in North billerica for 53 years, retiring in 1964."

record.text:
Amazing! My paternal grandma's grandpa, the obit mentions he worked at Talbot (his brother was there too in a different department.)

His father and older brothers in the 1870 census were listed as working at the Mills.

Wow that's so cool to know you can point to those roofs like "we did that!" üòÅ

images.alt: Obituary from a newspaper. The text reads "Mr (redacted by poster) had been employed as an overseer of the Spinning Department at Talbot Mills in North billerica for 53 years, retiring in 1964."

Black and white vintage photo of the Talbot Mills on the banks of the Merrimack river in Billerica, Massachusetts. It is a long five-story brick building with many large windows on each floor with a 7-8 story tower that has a cupola on top.

record.text:
This photo of the Talbot is from an  old postcard in my dad‚Äôs photo album. 
His grandmother worked there from probably about age 12-13 sometime after her arrival in 1872. She met and married her husband there, then he died young & she raised 4 kids alone on a mill girl‚Äôs salary.

images.alt: Black and white vintage photo of the Talbot Mills on the banks of the Merrimack river in Billerica, Massachusetts. It is a long five-story brick building with many large windows on each floor with a 7-8 story tower that has a cupola on top.

record.text: I grew up playing in and around this river (I‚Äôm not quite as old as the black and white photo!). It‚Äôs the river Cole in Coleshill and the bridge was first built in the 16th century and is still there! The water is possibly less clean!
